item.title: Elon Musk’s SpaceX Valued at $800 Billion, as It Prepares to Go Public
item.description: A sale of insider shares at $421 a share would make Mr. Musk’s rocket company the most valuable private company in the world, as it readies for a possible initial public offering next year.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The SpaceX launchpad in South Texas in June 2024. The company said in a letter to employees on Friday that it could go public in 2026.

item.title: Elon Musk Tests Europe’s Willingness to Enforce Its Online Laws
item.description: Backed by White House officials, the tech billionaire has lashed out at the European Union after his social media platform X was fined last week.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Elon Musk has grown increasingly confrontational toward Europe over the past year.

item.title: Trump Moves to Stop States From Regulating AI With a New Executive Order
item.description: The order would create one federal regulatory framework for artificial intelligence, President Trump told reporters in the Oval Office.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, who has said it’s important for America to dominate in the race to develop A.I., has said that the various state A.I. laws have created a confusing patchwork of regulations.

item.title: Australia Kicks Kids Off Social Media + Is the A.I. Water Issue Fake? + Hard Fork Wrapped
item.description: “I’m told that Australian teens, in preparation for this ban, have been exchanging phone numbers with each other.”
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Jen Poyant, Katie McMurran, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: David Gray/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Harold Hamm, Oklahoma Oil Tycoon, Allies With Trump to Reshape U.S. Energy
item.description: Harold Hamm, an Oklahoma oil tycoon, has played a central role in reshaping energy policy by allying himself with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: China Is Getting Much of What It Wants From the U.S., Including Chips
item.description: For China, President Trump’s moves to loosen chip controls, soften U.S. rhetoric and stay silent on tensions with Japan amount to a rare string of strategic gains.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, after their meeting in Busan, South Korea, in October. Mr. Trump’s latest moves extended the conciliatory posture he struck at this summit.

item.title: Do Kwon, Crypto Entrepreneur Who Caused 2022 Crash, Sentenced to 15 Years
item.description: Do Kwon, who designed the virtual currencies Luna and TerraUSD, which plunged in 2022, had pleaded guilty to fraud.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner and David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Risto Bozovic/Associated Press
item.media:description: Do Kwon, a crypto entrepreneur who went on the run after the crash of two virtual currencies that he created, was escorted by Montenegro police in 2024.

item.title: Can OpenAI Respond After Google Closes the A.I. Technology Gap?
item.description: A new technology release from OpenAI is supposed to top what Google recently produced. It also shows OpenAI is engaged in a new and more difficult competition.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
item.media:description: OpenAI’s newest technology comes after Google claimed it had topped its young competitor.

item.title: After Australia, Which Countries Could Be Next to Ban Social Media for Children
item.description: Governments are studying the decision to prohibit youths from using platforms like Facebook and TikTok as worries grow about the potential harm they cause.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Ida Marie Odgaard/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Elementary school children in Denmark, which could become the first country in the European Union to impose an age limit on access to social media.

item.title: Ford’s Car of the Future, Hatched in a Skunk Works Near Los Angeles
item.description: Desperate to catch up with Chinese automakers, Ford is redesigning its fleet with a Silicon Valley-style team. Is it too late?
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Field, Ford Motor Company’s chief of electric vehicles, digital and design.

item.title: How Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 Became a Gaming Tour de Force
item.description: Without a blockbuster budget or much experience, the creators of Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 astounded the industry with an emotional narrative and old-school design.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: Trump’s Interest in Warner Bros. Deal Weighs On Justice Department
item.description: President Trump’s unusual decision to involve himself in the government’s review of the deal puts pressure on his antitrust chief.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Pete Kiehart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gail Slater is in charge of the Department of Justice’s antitrust division, which is expected to handle the government’s review of a Warner Bros. deal.

item.title: Trump Administration Rules Threaten Nobel Prizes Won by Immigrants
item.description: As three immigrants claim Nobel Prizes in science for the United States this year, experts warn that immigration crackdowns could undo American innovation.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: Does the Job of C.E.O. or Private Investor Come First? Intel’s Chief Is Juggling That Question.
item.description: Lip-Bu Tan, who was appointed chief executive of Intel in March, is also a longtime venture capitalist. His dual roles have caused some consternation.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark and Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Laure Andrillon/Reuters
item.media:description: Lip-Bu Tan, the chief executive of Intel, has led a venture capital firm since 1987.

item.title: Meta’s New A.I. Superstars Are Chafing Against the Rest of the Company
item.description: An us-versus-them mentality has emerged between Meta’s top artificial intelligence team and longtime lieutenants to Mark Zuckerberg.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan
item.media:credit: Mikel Jaso

item.title: Chip Company Plotted to Send Technology to China, Ex-C.E.O. Says
item.description: The former chief executive of Nexperia, a Dutch chipmaker, said Dutch officials had known for years that the company’s Chinese owner sought to move its technology to China.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Fabian Bimmer/Reuters
item.media:description: On a production line of the Dutch semiconductor company Nexperia in Hamburg, Germany, last year. Dutch officials seized the company in September.

item.title: Trump’s Nvidia Chip Deal Reverses Decades of Technology Restrictions
item.description: President Trump’s decision to allow Nvidia to sell its chips to China has raised questions about whether he is prioritizing short-term economic gain over long-term American security interests.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, at the White House in April.

item.title: Some Teens Are on Social Media ‘Almost Constantly,’ Survey Says
item.description: The new Pew report also found that two-thirds of teens said they had used an A.I. chatbot.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Why the A.I. Boom Is Unlike the Dot-Com Boom
item.description: Silicon Valley is again betting everything on a new technology. But the mania is not a reboot of the late-1990s frenzy.
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld
item.media:credit: Joe Buglewicz/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Ben Horowitz, a major A.I. venture capitalist, in 2019. “The clearest sign that we are not actually in a bubble is the fact that everyone is talking about a bubble,” he said.

item.title: How Art Is Driving Waymo’s Feel-Good Branding
item.description: A tech giant has teamed up with local artists, adding vibrant colors and quirky characters in an effort to humanize its futuristic ride.
item.dc:creator: Jori Finkel
item.media:credit: Jamie Lee Taete for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Waymo self-driving car in Los Angeles wrapped with art by Tommii Lim. His cartoon cat is a stand-in for the target Waymo customer, who enjoys kicking back and relinquishing control of the wheel.

item.title: ‘Alan’s Universe’ Shows What It Might Look Like to Win at YouTube
item.description: As Gen Alpha’s attention drifts from TV and movies, video creators like Alan Chikin Chow are eager to fill the void.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Philip Cheung
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times

item.title: All 187,460 Miles of Road That Led to Rome, Mapped
item.description: A digital atlas of ancient Rome’s highways and byways reveals a road network that was more extensive than thought.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.media:credit: Jonathan Corum/The New York Times

item.title: ‘Marjorie Prime’ Review: A.I. Gave Her Back Her Husband. Was It Worth It?
item.description: June Squibb stars in the Broadway premiere of Jordan Harrison’s meditation on grief and the nature of human and artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: June Squibb, right, plays the titular character of “Marjorie Prime,” with Christopher Lowell as an A.I. replica of her deceased husband as he was in his 30s.

item.title: A.I. Videos Have Flooded Social Media. No One Was Ready.
item.description: Apps like OpenAI’s Sora are fooling millions of users into thinking A.I. videos are real, even when they include warning labels.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Who Is Andrew Ferguson, the FTC Chairman Who Tilted the Agency to Trump?
item.description: Andrew Ferguson has used the Federal Trade Commission’s consumer protection mandate to investigate issues important to President Trump and his base.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Ferguson, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, during a House Appropriations Subcommittee on Financial Services and General Government hearing in May.

item.title: App That Tracks ICE Raids Sues U.S., Saying Officials Pressured Apple to Remove It
item.description: The developer of ICEBlock, which notifies users of ICE agent sightings, said Attorney General Pam Bondi censored his free speech.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street raid by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents and other federal law enforcement officers along Canal Street in New York in October.

item.title: Flying Abroad? Get Ready for New Facial-Recognition Tech at Departure Gates.
item.description: New facial-recognition tools being tested at Orlando International Airport could soon be keeping track of travelers at departure gates across the country.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Jacob Langston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Biometric technology made by iProov is part of three identity-confirmation pilot programs at Orlando International Airport.

item.title: I Let Reddit Choose My Wedding Dress — and They Got It Right
item.description: It can be easier to talk to strangers, which might explain why Reddit has become an increasingly popular resource for wedding planning.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Diamond
item.media:credit: Irena Rudovska/iStock; Thomas Fuller/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images; Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: How Stablecoins Can Help Criminals Launder Money and Evade Sanctions
item.description: Through layers of intermediaries, stablecoins can be moved, swapped and mixed into pools of other funds in ways that are difficult to trace, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Krolik
item.media:credit: Jeremy Leung
